qas.question: What are the thermochemical cycyles in a testing phase for?

answers.text: produce hydrogen and oxygen from water and heat without using electricity

qas.question: What are labs trying to produce hydrogen from?

answers.text: France, Germany, Greece, Japan, and the USA

context: There are more than 200 thermochemical cycles which can be used for water splitting, around a dozen of these cycles such as the iron oxide cycle, cerium(IV) oxide–cerium(III) oxide cycle, zinc zinc-oxide cycle, sulfur-iodine cycle, copper-chlorine cycle and hybrid sulfur cycle are under research and in testing phase to <a0_0>produce hydrogen and oxygen from water and heat without using electricity<a0_0/>. A number of laboratories (including in <a2_0>France, Germany, Greece, Japan, and the USA<a2_0/>) are developing thermochemical methods to produce hydrogen from <a1_0>solar energy and water<a1_0/>.
